metadata.title: Taking Refuge from Bycatch Issues: Red King Crab (Paralithodes camtschaticus) and Trawl Fisheries in the Eastern Bering Sea

creators.name: University of Washington (UW), School of Aquatic

metadata.description:
Concerns about possibly heavy impacts of bottom trawl fisheries on red king
     crab (Paralithodes camtschaticus) pot fisheries in the eastern Bering Sea led
     in 1987 to an emergency closure of trawling in an area of adult and juvenile
     crab habitat. We examine the effectiveness of this bycatch refuge in protecting
     and possibly enhancing the crab resource using three approaches. First,
     bycatch of crab in trawl fisheries is a small proportion of total estimated
     abundance throughout the southeastern Bering Sea but may be high relative
     to stock abundance within the closed area and relative to annual crab landings;
     recent regulations have diminished this apparent effect. Effects of direct
     bycatch on the stock are obscured by lack of evidence on indirect effects of
     trawling, including crushing of crab and degradation of juvenile habitat.
     Second, surveys inside and outside the refuge before and after closure show
     no significant changes in abundance of female and prerecruit male crab. Third,
     important breeding and hatching grounds and juvenile habitat are not
     protected by the refuge, leaving long-term stock renewal subject to trawl
     impacts. We suggest that full consideration of the needs of all life history
     stages could lead to a more effective refuge design.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report the taking of refuge from bycatch issues: Red king crab (Paralithodes camtschaticus) and trawl fisheries in the eastern Bering Sea
